data.text: Contents
Introduction
This Policy is to ensure a standardised approach to the recording and escalation of adult patient's physiological observations utilising the National Early Warning Score 2nd ed. (NEWS2).

This policy is underpinned by the principle that recognises the importance of ensuring all adult patients' vital signs are accurately and promptly recorded by appropriately trained staff. Where patients' observations are outside of normal parameters or where there are signs of physiological deterioration, staff will take appropriate action to monitor the patient more closely and seek advice and support from other members of the Multidisciplinary Team. This aims to reverse or prevent further deterioration and avoidable harm to the patient. This policy is based on guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE, 2007) Guideline number 50 Acutely Ill Patients in Hospital. Recognition of and response to acute illness in adults in hospital, in conjunction with the Royal College of Physicians (2017). National Early Warning Score Second Edition (NEWS2) Standardising the assessments of acute illness severity in the NHS

This policy aims to support the appropriate measuring, recording and escalation of patient's physiological observations in accordance with the National Early Warning Score Second Edition (NEWS2). It aims to depict the roles and responsibilities of different staff members in regards to escalating and responding to the deteriorating patient.
Scope

This policy sets out the standards, expected for the care of adult patients within the acute hospital setting. This relates to the measurement and recording of physiological observations and the use of a ‘track and trigger' system to ensure patients who are deteriorating are recognised and treated in an appropriate and timely manner by competent staff.

The policy enables the Trust to adhere to the NCEPOD 2012 recommendation for optimising early warning scoring systems “Time to Intervene”, the NICE 2007 Guideline  on “Acutely Ill Patients in Hospital” and more recently the Royal College of Physicians National Early Warning Score 2012. All three recognise that patients in the acute setting can rapidly deteriorate and the widespread use of track and trigger systems identifies the early signs and symptoms of a deteriorating patient.
The policy excludes paediatric and maternity patients who, owing to their specialist requirements are managed within their own speciality and follow their specialty specific escalation policies
The purpose of this document:
Applies to adult patients in the acute inpatient setting, this will include the adult Emergency Department and associated assessment areas, for example Same Day Emergency Care.
Applies to adult patients having invasive procedures (including Radiology and endoscopy)
This policy applies to all health care practitioners who measure, record and respond to patients' physiological observations.
Have a clear monitoring plan, determined by the appropriate electronic observations system that specifies which physiological observations should be recorded, and how often.
Have physiological observations recorded at least every 6 hours and the frequency increased if abnormal physiology is detected.

Monitored using a relevant physiological track and trigger system. The track and trigger system will identify the appropriate graded response to abnormal physiological observations recorded or guide clinicians.
Non acute inpatient sites will be excluded
Definitions

An electronic technology system that is available on hand held devices, allowing staff to record clinical observation, assessments and data, whilst calculating score, balances, and producing ‘soft' alerting (visual prompts) for the deteriorating patient. The system produces electronic charts that can be viewed by multiple users, in all clinical areas on site.

Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation is a clinical decision made by the patient's responsible clinician or directly by the patient. For a patient having a DNACPR status identifies they will not receive treatments such as chest compressions or defibrillation in the event their heart stops
The Glasgow Coma Scale provides a practical method for assessment of impairment of conscious level in response to defined stimuli.

Medical emergency teams are activated by switchboard using the emergency telephone number 2222. There are a range of teams that can be activated. For the purpose of this policy the team referred to is the adult
medical emergency team. The medical emergency team will respond to any 2222 call made for clinical and non-clinical areas within the hospital or the hospital grounds.

National Early Warning Score is a nationally agreed assessment tool where a scoring of a patients physiological observations that can be calculated at the point of care, using individually identified parameters to identify the unwell and/or deteriorating patient and guides clinical staff in the further assessment, escalation and review.

A team of specialised nurses with the expertise to directly intervene or facilitate a multi-disciplinary approach in the identification of patients at risk of developing critical illness and those patients recovering from a period of critical illness to enable early intervention or transfer (if appropriate) to an area suitable for care for that patient's individual needs.
Situation, Background, Assessment and Recommendation is an effective framework for optimising clear communication between members of the health care team regarding a patient's condition
A documented plan identifying the ceiling of treatment and intervention for a patient.

Measures of various statistics taken by clinical staff in order to assess a patient's fundamental physiological function, such as pulse, temperature, systolic blood pressure, respiratory rate, CAVPU (the level to which the patient responds) and oxygen saturation, plus the patient's inspired oxygen requirements.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Deteriorating Patient Working Group
The procedural document is up to date, technically accurate, is in line with evidence based best practice and has been produced following consultation with stakeholders
Through the Chair, to provide assurance on the effectiveness of this policy and the Trust's procedures for the identification and management of the deteriorating patient.
Managing Director

The Managing Director as the Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director/Director of Nursing

Is responsible for ensuring that the standards and expectations of staff under this policy are clear, available, and implemented and dissemination through professional lines of accountability and that suitable arrangement are in place to measure outcome and compliance.
Divisional Clinical Directors

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout their Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of this document.
Consultant Leads
Have the responsibility to ensure the clinical areas and staff in their Divisions implement and comply with the policy.
Divisional General Managers

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions, to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Heads of Nursing

The Heads of Nursing Quality and Assurance are responsible for ensuring that this document is fully implemented at clinical l departmental level. This will include making sure all relevant and necessary training is given and recorded, that the introduction of the document is monitored and the impact on service delivery is assessed through audit with adequate resources to support ongoing review.

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Matrons, Lead Nurses and Senior Sisters/Charge Nurses

Have responsibility for education and implementation of this policy within their allocated clinical area, ensuring staff understand their accountability and responsibility in relation to complying with the policy and ongoing audit and review of compliance.
Medical Staff

Appropriate Medical Staff should ensure that the appropriate identified parameters are set for patients recognising individual chronic physiological conditions to ensure appropriate assessment escalation and treatment when indicated. There should be a clear treatment escalation plan (TEP) for all patients that is written and agreed.
Registered Nurses

Registered Nurses must ensure personal competence in the completion and recording of observations. Where patients trigger NEWS 2 and/or the patient required intervention they must ensure prompt and appropriate response and escalation as indicated by the actions in accordance with NEWS
Any delegation of duty regarding the taking and recording of observation must be to a member of staff that has been deemed competent to carry out that duty and report abnormalities as indicated.
Associate Practitioners
All Associate Practitioners involved in the taking and recording of patient observations must be deemed competent by the Senior Sister/Charge Nurse of the ward/area

All Associate Practitioners involved in the monitoring of patients must ensure that any abnormality is reported and escalated in accordance with the clinical response criteria outlined on as per MSE NEWS2 escalation. (Appendix 2)
Health Care Assistants (HCAs)
All HCAs involved in the taking and recording of patient observations must be deemed competent by the Senior Sister/Charge Nurse of the ward/area

All HCAs involved in the monitoring of patients must ensure that any abnormality is reported and escalated in accordance with the clinical response criteria outlined as per MSE NEWS2 escalation. (Appendix 2)
Aim of the policy
The aim of this policy is to standardise the processes by which the patients who are acutely ill or at risk of physical deterioration, are identified and responded to.
The Trust uses the National Early Warning Scoring (NEWS2) for adult patients and graded response system to detect and monitor patients who are acutely ill or at risk of physical deterioration.
During an adult in-patient or elective admission/ day case episode all patient observations are recorded and scored as per NEWS2 scoring system detailed in Appendix
All physiological observations must be recorded and acted upon by staff that are trained to undertake these physiological observation and understand their clinical relevance.
All patients must have physiological observations recorded at the time of admission or initial assessment, including patients in the Emergency Department.
NEWS2 will detail which physiological observations should be recorded, and how often. In addition it should be recorded on the appropriate electronic observation system.

All patient must have physiological observations performed and recorded 6 hourly as a minimum frequency, unless clearly documented otherwise in the healthcare records. Observation frequency should increase accordance to the physiological parameter score identified in MSE NEWS2 escalation protocol or, if there is cause for concern (Appendix 2)
When a patient's NEWS 2 score triggers an escalation, any requirements for intervention are clearly documented within the patients' Healthcare Records.

Early signs of deterioration: such as new confusion or agitation; change in behaviour; reduced urine output; drowsiness; generally feeling or looking unwell; reduced mobility; and refusing food or fluid may precede or replace those recorded in routine physiological monitoring. This is particularly important for patients who have difficulties with communication (for example, patients with dementia and learning disabilities). Clinical staff should be alert to these alternative signs and escalate patients who are causing concern to either them or the patient's relatives/carers, irrespective of the NEWS2 score.
Escalation and recording of physiological observation need to be followed:-
A senior medical review, where the frequency of observation has been decreased and the decision clearly documented in the patient's healthcare records.
Where a Patient has been placed on End of Life Pathway/ Palliative care.
Escalation

NEWS2 is an aid to clinical assessment and is not a substitute for competent clinical judgement. Concern about a patient's clinical condition should always override the NEWS2 prompts if the Healthcare professional considers it necessary to increase the frequency of monitoring. Whilst the NEWS2 system facilitates the assessment, early recognition and response to the deteriorating patient it should not deter health care practitioners from exercising their clinical judgement and therefore escalating appropriately. Such decisions should be clearly documented in the patient's healthcare records.

The MSE NEWS2 escalation protocol (Appendix 2) is a framework to ensure that a clinician with the appropriate expertise to respond is called to attend within a specified timeframe,(see table 2) this will ensure that patients who are acutely ill or at risk of physical deterioration receive prompt care and decisions are made in a timely manner.
The responder to the escalation is responsible for informing colleagues if they are unable to attend within the requested time frame to enable an alternative clinician to be contacted.
Following escalation the clinician assessing the patient is responsible for ensuring an appropriate plan for ongoing monitoring further escalation and/or an alternative responder are in place.
The person responding must document their actions and management plan in the patients' Healthcare records.

To improve communication between clinical staff it is recommended that referrals and handovers (including the initial call for escalation) utilise the SBAR format (Situation-Background-Assessment- Recommendation (Appendix 3)
Patients with a DNACPR but still for active treatment must still have their observations performed and be escalated as per this policy.
Response to NEWS2 Score and escalation
Frequency of Physiological observation
7.1.1 Once the total NEWS2 score has been calculated, the person performing and recording the physiological observation will respond according to the MSE NEWS2 Escalation protocol (Appendix 2)
7.1.2 Frequency of physiological Observation / monitoring of a deteriorating patient will depend on the NEWS2 Score (Chart 1) or as decided following the deteriorating patients review and assessment.

data.text: 7.1.3 Some clinical situations may require observations to be taken outside of the standard frequency such as post-surgery, blood transfusion or a personalised NEWS2 required for patients under lining medical conditions, the frequency should only be changed by a clinical member of staff or a Registered Nurse on the electronic observation system.
7.1.4 The person performing and recording the physiological observations that trigger an escalation response must document the time and person escalated to.
Escalation graded response

7.2.1 Following  a  NEWS2  trigger,  an  initial  assessment  should  be  carried  out  by  a Registered Nurse with further escalation as per MSE NEWS2 escalation protocol (Appendix 2) to ensure that a clinician with the appropriate expertise to respond is called to attend within a specified timeframe (Chart 2). This will ensure that patients who are acutely ill or at risk of physical deterioration receive prompt care and decisions are made in a timely manner.

data.text: 7.2.2 In the absence of a response (review or telephone advice as appropriate) from the Medical Team or Outreach within the specified timeframe of the initial escalation then, the relevant individuals should be re-contacted by the Registered Nurse and/or the patient should be escalated to a more senior doctor. If a patient's
NEWS2 score has deteriorated further since the initial escalation, then the next level of escalation should be based on the new NEWS2 score.

7.2.3 If there is no response from the contacted responder (see chart 2) and the Registered Nurse/Senior Nurse on duty have immediate clinical concerns then a Medical Emergency Team call is to be placed (2222).
7.2.4 Any failure to respond to an escalation must be documented in the patient's Healthcare Records.
7.2.5 A clinical review, due to physiological deterioration, should include:
A thorough review of the history and physical examination.
The formulation of a clear medical plan with appropriate investigations and interventions.
A review of the Treatment Escalation Plan (TEP).
Appropriate documentation, discussion / involvement of senior colleagues where the review occurs by junior staff.
Clearly documented and communicated Management Plans for ward staff to follow in case of further deterioration or failure to respond to intervention.
Outreach
7.3.1 Providing specialist advice, support and treatment to the deteriorating patient seven days a week, including weekends and bank holidays.
7.3.2 Any patient that deteriorates and has a NEWS2 score of 5 or 6 can be escalated to the Outreach team, for telephone advice or support.
7.3.3 If a patient has a NEWS2 score of 7 or above they should be escalated to the on- call medical registrar /Outreach Team immediately.
Urine output
7.4.1 Urine output is not one of the patients observations used in the NEWS 2 score. However it is a very useful clinical indicator for patient deterioration.
7.4.2 If a patient's score is a moderate or high risk priority for deterioration then a fluid management chart must be commenced if not already in use.

7.4.3 If urine output drops below 0.5mls/ kg / hour per hour, for more than 4 hours then the patient will be escalated as a moderate priority risk, providing urinary retention has been excluded. (Refer to AKI pathway)
Neurological Observations:

7.5.1 Patients requiring neurological observations should be monitored using physiological observation, Glasgow Coma Score being completed at each set of physiological observations as well as observation of pupils, and limb response and documented via electronic observation system.

7.5.2 The NEWS2 and new confusion: The inclusion of ‘new confusion' (including disorientation, delirium or any acute reduction in GCS score) as part of the assessment of consciousness on the NEWS2 chart.
7.5.3 If it is unclear whether a patient's confusion is ‘new' or their usual state, the altered mental state/confusion should be assumed to be new until confirmed to be otherwise.

7.5.4 A Register Nurse or Doctor must immediately recheck a drop in the patient's GCS score of 2 or more points, or 1 point sustained for ½ hour. If the drop in GCS is confirmed it must be urgently reported to a middle grade doctor or Consultant from the patient's team/ on-call team, or Outreach (Moderate Priority escalation). Patients with a GCS falling to 8 or less must be urgently referred to a middle grade (SPR) or above (High risk Priority escalation).
De-Escalation

Following an escalation for deterioration, decisions on further escalation parameters should be clearly documented in the healthcare records by the responding clinician. This should include decisions on future NEWS2 triggers, ceiling of care, frequency of physiological observations and a clear indication of the duration of such management decisions (to indicate when the patient should return to the standard escalation pathway, Appendix 2)
End of life/ Palliative Care

For many patients the intended purpose of this policy is to ensure there is adequate monitoring and escalation to provide active treatment/ care, but for other patients further treatment and care may be ineffective and often there has been a decision to offer best supportive and palliative care.

Where best supportive and palliative care is being offered, the monitoring of patients should change and be individualised to meet the patient's specific palliative needs and their priorities of care.
For patients in the last days of life, physiological observations may not be required as part of their care and they should be excluded from having observations recorded.

As part of dying, it may be necessary for staff to perform an observation if it helps with symptom control and the patient's management, e.g. a temperature may be taken so an anti-pyretic can be administered to maintain comfort or oxygen saturation may be taken to guide staff.
Training requirements
Education and training must be provided to ensure staffs have these skills and abilities and they will be assessed to demonstrate competency, by divisional educators, and competent practitioners.
All Healthcare Professionals caring for adult patients are expected to attend / complete NEWS2 training.

All staff caring for patients must be competent in the monitoring, measurement, interpretation and prompt response to the deteriorating / acutely ill patient appropriate to the level of care they are providing.

Induction and on-going NEWS 2 training will be incorporated into personal development plans as part as the appraisal process and staff performance review. Update training will be required when national changes occur.
All clinical and nursing staff will need to complete the NEWS 2 Deteriorating Patient and e-Obs, e‐ learning package.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Deteriorating Patient working group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Deteriorating Patient Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
